awd_titl_txt: CCF:Small:Collaborative Research: Taowu: A Heterogeneous Processing-in-Memory for High Performance Scientific Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Many scientific computing applications in critical areas of research, such as nanotechnology, astrophysics, climate, bioinformatics, and high-energy physics, are becoming more data intensive than ever before. The volume of the data and the pressure on the runtime system capability of supporting data intensive operations substantially increases over the time. This project introduces and optimizes data processing capabilities within memory. The project provides a fundamental change to data management and program optimization, and brings promising performance and energy benefits. The project will significantly advance simulation capabilities of scientific applications, especially those with intensive data processing. 
 
The goal of the project is to enable high-performance, energy-efficient, and flexible processing-in-memory design, which is adaptive to the irregular, diverse, and changing behaviors among data intensive scientific applications. To achieve the goal, a heterogeneous processing-in-memory design, built up with fixed-function processing-in-memory and general programmable processing-in-memory, is introduced. The project explores a series of critical questions for building emerging processing-in-memory, including heterogeneous processing-in-memory architecture, processing-in-memory programming models, runtime design, and the implications of processing-in-memory on high performance scientific applications. The  project will significantly advance the knowledge to build processing-in-memory, and pave the way to integrate it into the existing and future systems.

por.por_cntn:
We introduce a new architecture, the heterogeneous PIM which combines the benefits of and avoid the limitation of fixed function PIMs and programmable PIM. We show that such architecture is highly beneficial for emerging workloads (e.g., machine learning training) and high-performance computing (HPC) applications (e.g., density functional theory-based ab initio quantum chemistry method).

 

We study how to program the heterogeneous PIM and what is the optimal scheduling policy. Our programming method and runtime techniques are useful for the HPC community to address the hardware heterogeneity problem.

 

We apply the heterogeneous PIM to the research of using machine learning models to approximate some computation in HPC applications. Given the success story of our work, the heterogeneous PIM provides new opportunities to scientific machine learning and calls for new machine learning models to get most out of the heterogeneous PIM for HPC applications.

 

We also apply the heterogeneous PIM to mobile devices to enable training of machine learning models. The mobile devices have very limited memory bandwidth (in contrast to large memory bandwidth on regular servers), which imposes challenges of running some data-intensive applications on mobile devices. Using the heterogeneous PIM in the mobile devices enhances the functionality of those mobile services (e.g., training machine learning models).

 

Our work makes the large natural langauage processing (NLP) models approachable by small institutes with small financial budgets, accelerating the adoption of those most recent large NLP models. Our work is adopted by an AI framework to train large AI models (https://github.com/hpcaitech/ColossalAI) and reported by several medias.

 

This project includes the development of hardware- and software-based techniques. Students involved in the project have good hands-on experiences to understand how the system stacks (including applications, runtime, and architecture) work. Those experiences are very useful to develop students’ skills in computer science and engineering. 

 

The project is based on collaborations with a couple of institutes, such as Pacific Northwest National Lab (PNNL) and Microsoft. The project provides student internship opportunities and includes minority students and undergraduate students.

Modified by: Dong Li
